thread.title: Bucks Travel To Huron To Begin Final Stretch Of Season
thread.title_full: Bucks Travel To Huron To Begin Final Stretch Of Season

author: JEREMY HOECK jeremy.hoeck@yankton.net
title: Bucks Travel To Huron To Begin Final Stretch Of Season
text:
Bucks Travel To Huron To Begin Final Stretch Of Season BY JEREMY HOECK jeremy.hoeck@yankton.net yankton.net | 0 comments 
The final third of the regular season presents a critical juncture for the Yankton football team. 
At 3-3 and coming off consecutive shutouts, the Bucks spent a bulk of this week not talking about formations or schemes, but confidence, according to head coach Arlin Likness. 
“We have to gain confidence, confidence and more confidence,” said Likness, whose Bucks visit Huron tonight (Friday) for a 7 p.m. Eastern South Dakota Conference contest. 
“We need to show that some of the things we’re doing are the right things and start to believe in each other a little more.” 
Having come out of its latest, tough four-game stretch with one win, Yankton now kick-starts the final three games of the regular season tonight against a Huron (2-4) squad it has beaten in 20 straight matchups. 
Yet for the Bucks, they aren’t simply assuming they’ll venture to Huron and right the ship after back-to-back shutouts (in which they committed 12 turnovers), Likness said. 
“It’s not about winning and losing right now, it’s about getting better,” he said. “You have to start there first.” 
That’s exactly the situation facing Huron first-year head coach Michael Schmitz. 
Schmitz, a former player at Brandon Valley most recently an assistant at Huron, inherited a Tigers program that was 8-40 over the previous five seasons. He brought a new system to the fold this season, he said this week. 
“I have a definite different system than what they’re used to,” Schmitz said. “We have different terminology and the way we do things.” 
Huron, ranked eighth out of nine teams in Class 11AA, is coming off a 20-14 win over Spearfish and showed flashes of progress, Schmitz said. 
“We didn’t fall apart when we got down, he said. “They put their heads down for a minute, and then bounced back. And that was a step in the right direction.” 
The Tigers have been primarily a passing offense – Likness guessed it was around 60 percent of the time – and are led by junior quarterback Hyland Heinz. He has completed 97-of-171 (57 percent) of his passes for nine touchdowns with seven interceptions. 
Senior Trey Moeding has a team-high 21 catches for 239 yards and two touchdowns, while 6-foot-5 junior Tye Evers (10-265, 3 TD) and senior Greg Conrad (20-175, 2 TD) are also offensive weapons for the Tigers. 
“It will test our secondary, which will be good for us,” Likness said. “We’ve come a long way since our first game and if we can feel comfortable and make plays, that will really help us.” 
Huron does not have a rusher that has accumulated 100 yards this season, but the Tigers being able to move the chains to keep their defense off the field is a key, Schmitz said. 
“Offensively, we have to be able to move the ball on the ground and get first downs,” he said. “That’s been our problem, the lack of first downs.” 
Those would certainly be keys for Yankton as well, but the Bucks right now are working on their confidence, Likness said. 
“If we can do that, we’ll have turned the corner and maybe start heading in the right direction,” he said. 
Follow @jhoeck on Twitter 
Yankton (3-3) at Huron (2-4) 
7 p.m., Huron 
LAST MEETING: Yankton opened the 2014 Class 11AA playoffs with a 43-21 victory over Huron on Oct. 30. It was the Bucks’ 20th straight victory over the Tigers. 
LAST WEEK: Yankton dropped a 35-0 decision to Sioux Falls O’Gorman. Huron beat Spearfish 20-14 for its second victory of the season 
NEXT UP: Yankton hosts Douglas for the first time in the playoff era. With its home schedule complete, Huron heads to Sioux Falls to face O’Gorman. 
FOLLOW THE GAME: Jeremy Hoeck (@jhoeck) and James D. Cimburek (@jcimburek) will follow the Bucks all season. Follow them on Twitter to keep up with the action.
